The first pair of pillow blocks worked fine so printed the other 7 with nuts and 7 without.

Sometimes you feel like a nut, sometimes you don't.

media.description: Printed the platforms for the carriage and gantries.
media.title: 20151222_082307.jpg

media.description: Y axis gantries flanking the X axis carriage plate

media.description: Pillow blocks with gantries and carriage
media.title: 20151222_083008.jpg

media.description:
Detaching the raft from the parts and from the bed of the machine is often challenging.

("There's got to be a better way!")
media.title: 20151222_084315.jpg

media.description: The blue clear filament is slightly different from the red filament used to print the calibration targets which resulted in the holes being close but undersized.  This was easily fixed by tapping the holes... I'm glad they were undersized and not oversized.
media.title: 20151222_091404.jpg

media.description:
One Y axis gantry.

The top pillow blocks will simply support the horizontal threaded rods.  The bottom pillow blocks each capture a nut facing each direction.  The nice thing is that once you seat one nut, you can adjust the orientation of the other to minimize backlash as you thread the rod through.  Each nut has 6 possible orientations on a 20tpi rod resulting in adjustments of 1/120" for each 60 degree rotation of the nut.
media.title: 20151222_093000.jpg

media.description: Gantries and carriage nearly complete.
media.title: 20151222_093029.jpg

media.description: Hand cranks for X and Y axes in MakerBot Desktop being printed (Orange) and in OpenSCAD (Yellow).
media.title: 20151222_093415.jpg

media.description: Printed hand cranks.
media.title: 20151222_103318.jpg

media.description: Printed hand cranks.
media.title: 20151222_103338.jpg

media.description: I printed without support material and had some dangling strands.  Not unexpected and easily cleaned up with little scissors.
media.title: 20151222_103502.jpg

media.description: Gantry with a crank.
media.title: 20151222_104808.jpg

media.description:
At the hardware store taking note of the prices and availability of various dimensions, materials, and finishes of threaded rod.  
For this project I just used most of a five foot Allthread Plated  1/4"-20 threaded rod $5.99.
media.title: 20151222_111435.jpg

media.description: I realized that pulleys and fishing line would slip resulting in the rods not turning at the same rate and the machine ultimately binding, and at this point was considering using bicycle chain.
media.title: 20151222_113552.jpg

media.description:
I decided to experiment with ball chain.

#10 (@$1.79/ft) and #6 (@$1.49/ft) ball chain to be exact.
media.title: 20151222_114124.jpg

media.description: I gathered up all the round things I could find that were about the size of the crank to measure to make the sprocket.
media.title: 20151222_131217.jpg

media.description: I realized early on that the connector would be a problem with any sprocket because it was a little less than 3 balls long and it would not fit into a standard ball chain sprocket.
media.title: 20151222_141849.jpg

media.description: Amazingly, this empty tape spool's exterior diameter was exactly the inner diameter of 21 balls worth of chain wrapped around a cylinder.
media.title: 20151222_141917.jpg

media.description: The connector is closer in size to three balls worth of chain when wrapped around this cylinder than when straight.
media.title: 20151222_142041.jpg

media.description: I realized that if I designed a sprocket that would accept connectors, that each set of 3 balls would be captured in each connector pocket in the sprocket.
media.title: 20151222_143336.jpg

media.description:
Connector based ball chain sprocket.
It was handy that the diameter of the tape cylinder fit 21 beads: at 3 beads per connector it would fit exactly 7 connectors around.
media.title: 20151222_143353.jpg

media.description:
VERY close and I am happy with this first try.

The diameters are a little too small, and the width is a little too narrow which led to skipping every so often and the connector would not seat fully in the sprocket where it should.
media.title: 20151222_145118.jpg

media.description: Here you can see the connector sitting a little high and each batch of 3 balls on either side bulging out because it is a little too small.
media.title: 20151222_145158.jpg

media.description: Ball chain sprocket version 2
media.title: 20151222_155139.jpg

media.description: It's larger and you can see that the sides of the pockets are angled outward to receive the bead more smoothly.
media.title: 20151222_155145.jpg

media.description: This worked very well, I'm quite happy with it.
media.title: 20151222_162317.jpg

media.description: Clearly the chain and connector fit much better in this one and I really like how it fits neatly behind the handle.
media.title: 20151222_162341.jpg

media.description:
Time to cut the threaded rod.  
I have some tips for those of you who have not doe this before:

1. ALWAYS WEAR EYE PROTECTION AND BE VERY CAREFUL.  Small slivers of metal can be very damaging especially to your eyes.  If you work around metalwork be sure to tell people at the hospital because an MRI can cause more damage.
2. When marking where the cut should be, roll the rod until the mark falls exactly into a valley, it will be the easiest place to start the cut.
3. Thread nuts onto the threaded rod on either side of the cut.  These will help guide the saw, and even better, they will dress the threads as you unscrew them over the cut end.
4. Do not hold the threads in the vise, the steel jaws will flatten and destroy them.  Either grab them between pieces of wood or grab the nut as seen here.
5. Support the ends of the rod so it does not bend.  This piece has nearly 4 feet extending off to the left, if unsupported the rod would probably have bent making it unsuitable especially for this application.
media.title: 20151222_164439.jpg

media.description: The cut end on the vice side.
media.title: 20151222_164622.jpg

media.description: The cut end of the piece that was unsupported, note the piece of thread still attached at the top right.
media.title: 20151222_164630.jpg

media.description: Still clamping the nut which I have not removed yet, I threaded a little more rod through and will aggressively file the end flat and chamfer approximately 45 degrees all the way around the end of the threaded rod.
media.title: 20151222_164804.jpg

media.description:
Filed end.

Now you can back the threaded rod out of the nut and more importantly, be able to thread nuts onto the end easily.
media.title: 20151222_164901.jpg

media.description:
Cutting more rod.
Start between the nuts with shorter controlled strokes, then once started you can move to easy long strokes.  Don't force the saw, let the teeth do the work, as with any saw, as long as you are seeing metal filings (or sawdust) come out the cut is progressing.  The nuts also help you cut perpendicular to the rod rather than with the slope of the threads.
media.title: 20151222_170006.jpg

media.description:
An assembled Y axis and mostly assembled X axis (no knobs or chains)

The chain needs to be a multiple of 3 balls long, if not then when the connector returns it will not be aligned with a slot in the sprocket.  
When placing the chain on the machine make sure the machine is not racked.  The easiest way to do this is to bring both carriages all the way towards the near pillow blocks.
Start by lining up the slots on both pulleys to be straight up and place the connector in a slot on one pulley while winding the chain onto the other pulley.  Crank the chain around and see if the connector falls into a slot on the second pulley.  If it does not, remove the chain and try again, this time with the second pulley either advanced or retarded one ball as needed.
media.title: 20151222_204435.jpg

media.description:
I did not cut the chain to test the length, presumably that is what the hole in the connector is for (not present in the #6 ball chain connectors).
Once I got he length where I wanted it and counted the balls around the chain to be a multiple of three (twice) I marked the chain in the connector with the red pen.  Then I removed the connector from the chain, cut where the red mark was and could reassemble the now complete chain.
media.title: 20151222_204737.jpg

media.description:
Two axes!
It is not yet mounted but great fun to play with this VERY slow etch-a-sketch like apparatus.
For the capacitors I was going to mount it to this HDPE cutting board, but the rounded corners compromise all 4 of the outside mounting holes.
media.title: 20151222_232457.jpg

media.description: Coincidentally, the apparatus happened to be nearly exactly the size of a sheet of notebook paper, so I cut a piece of plywood to use as the base from a piece of scrap left over from the cocktail coin op project (https://picasaweb.google.com/102303773171415008577/110102CocktailCoinOpCabinet?authuser=0&feat=directlink).
media.title: 20151225_131012.jpg

media.description: I found some long thin wood (or plastic) screws in a drawer of salvaged floppy drive and toy parts.  Here I am testing the pilot hole size.
media.title: 20151225_150032.jpg

media.description:
Marked locations for pillow block installation by installing left bracket with the left screw and tensioning the chain by hand then using the punch to mark the remaining 3 hole locations.
Note the tape on the drill bit to let me know how deep to drill without coming out the back of the wood into my bench.
media.title: 20151225_150652.jpg

media.description: Took the measurements from the front and transferred them to the back to mount the pillow blocks at the other end of the Y axis.
media.title: 20151225_151055.jpg

media.description:
Fully assembled.
I even added some rubber feet for gription.
media.title: 20151225_152448.jpg

media.description: The two 2.5"x5" pieces of paper represent metal plates that will be mounted to the base.  Over the plates will be a thin sheet of dialectric material, and below the carriage will be a third metal plate that will be capacitively coupled to the sheets below.  The green sponge below the carriage will provide even constant pressure to the floating plate.  The vertical position of the top plate adjusts the amount of capacitative coupling, and the horizontal position allows the relative coupling to the left and right base plate.
media.title: 20151225_203047.jpg

media.description:
Using different thicknesses of hard and soft sponge to control the amount of pressure.

Also note that any of the threaded rods can optionally be driven either by a stepper or gear motor with feedback to adjust the system optimally fully automatically.
media.title: 20151225_203600.jpg

media.description:
20 turns per inch with very little backlash provides very fine reproducible control of the motion.

This is before I put rubber feet on it, it scoots too much and I had to shoot the video with one hand.
media.title: 20151225_152458.mp4

media.description:
A better look at the machine.

The rubber feet make a big difference in both gripping the counter top and in giving just a little more clearance for my fingers on the Y axis handle.
media.title: 20151225_152711.mp4
